title: AB 2561
content: The State of California enacts the following. Section 10912 of the Water Code defines various types of projects, including residential developments, shopping centers, commercial office buildings, hotels, industrial plants, and renewable energy facilities. The Water Code defines a project as any proposed development that would increase a public water system's service connections by 10% or more, or a mixed-use project requiring a significant amount of water. A public water system serves piped water to the public for human consumption and includes collection, treatment, storage, and distribution facilities. Section 10912 of the Water Code defines a "project" as a proposed development such as residential developments, shopping centers, commercial office buildings, and hotels with specific criteria. This section will be in effect until January 1, 2018, unless extended or repealed by a later statute. A "project" as defined in Section 10912 of the Water Code includes proposed developments like hotels with more than 500 rooms, industrial plants occupying over 40 acres of land, mixed-use projects, and developments requiring a significant amount of water. If a public water system has fewer than 5,000 service connections, a project is any proposed development that would increase the system's connections by 10% or more. (c) “Public water system” means a system for providing piped water to the public for human consumption with 3,000 or more service connections, including facilities under the operator's control and water treatment for safety. This section will be effective on January 1, 2018. If costs are mandated by the state, reimbursement will be made to local agencies and school districts. This act is an urgency statute aimed at promoting the development of photovoltaic and wind generation facilities to meet renewable energy goals and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. It is necessary for the act to take effect immediately.
